Microsoft's Server and Tools Business-in many ways the epicenter of its cloud strategy-is primed to undergo a shakeup this year with the departure of longtime division president Bob Muglia. While Windows and Office are household words, our Server and Tools business has quietly and steadily grown to be the unquestioned leader in server computing, Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer wrote in a Jan. 10 email to employees announcing Muglia's removal. "We are now ready to build on our success and move forward into the era of cloud computing."

domineering former US defense secretary- the late Robert McNamara - who came to describe the Vietnam War as "terribly wrong." "That's not the case with Iraq," Donald Rumsfeld said. I think the world's a better place with[ former Iraqi president] Saddam Hussein gone and with the Taliban gone and the al-Qaeda out of Afghanistan, he said, adding that the President Bush administration's decision to invade Iraq in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks on the US was "incremental," not rushed.

Google has shocked its shareholders by announcing that Eric Schmidt , its current CEO, is to step down in April and co-founder Larry Page will replace him in the chief executive officer role. When I joined Google in 2001 I never imagined, even in my wildest dreams, that we would get as far, as fast as we have today , starts Eric Schmidt in a post on the company's blog, while also posting on Twitter that the move was no longer about needing to supervise founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin : "Day-to-day adult supervision is

Once he got the chance. Coming off the bench for the first time as a Piston, Allen Iverson scored 17 points and led Detroit to a 107-97 victory over the slumping Milwaukee Bucks. "With everything going on, I wanted to play well, Allen Iverson said. "I just wanted to play well. Especially for my teammates because I let them down by not being here." David Cameron is said to be so worried about the prospect of losing legislation in a parliamentary logjam that he held a series of meetings with MPs and peers last week described as a "charm offensive". The Prime Minister is definitely in listening mode as never before, said one Conservative David Cameron . "He is much more conciliatory, the mood music has completely changed."
